snippet: CURTIS--<PERSON>Charles Buckley</PERSON>, family originally settled <LOCATION>Stratford</LOCATION>, CT <DATE>1734</DATE>, passed <DATE>December 21</DATE>, <LOCATION>2014 Peterborough</LOCATION>, NH. Born <DATE>October 14, 1929</DATE>, child <PERSON>Isobel Ramsay Buckley John Talbot Curtis</PERSON>. Chas grew...
lead_paragraph: CURTIS--<PERSON>Charles Buckley</PERSON>, whose family originally settled <LOCATION>Stratford</LOCATION>, CT in <DATE>1734</DATE>, passed away on <DATE>December 21, 2014</DATE> in <LOCATION>Peterborough</LOCATION>, NH. Born <DATE>October 14, 1929</DATE>, he was the first child of <PERSON>Isobel Ramsay Buckley</PERSON> and <PERSON>John Talbot Curtis</PERSON>. Chas grew up in <LOCATION>Southport</LOCATION>, CT and graduated from <LOCATION>Deerfield</LOCATION> in <DATE>1947</DATE> and <ORGANIZATION>Yale</ORGANIZATION> in <DATE>1951</DATE>. He rose to Executive Officer and Navigator in the <LOCATION>United States Navy</LOCATION>, following a long line of military and naval service stretching back to <PERSON>Silas Talbot</PERSON>, Captain of the <ORGANIZATION>U.S.S. Constitution</ORGANIZATION>. Early in his career he joined Pepperidge Farm and became <ORGANIZATION>General Plant Manager</ORGANIZATION> in <LOCATION>Norwalk</LOCATION>, <LOCATION>CT</LOCATION>. Chas then joined <ORGANIZATION>White</ORGANIZATION>, <ORGANIZATION>Weld & Co.</ORGANIZATION> to pursue a long-held interest in stock picking and portfolio management. He ultimately retired at 72 as Senior Vice President of <ORGANIZATION>UBS</ORGANIZATION>, having retained many of his original clients. Making turns into his eighties, <PERSON>Chas</PERSON> had a lifelong interest in skiing, first courting his wife of fifty-seven years, <PERSON>Ellen Martin Whitaker</PERSON>, at <LOCATION>Mad River Glen</LOCATION>. They later introduced their three boys to the <ORGANIZATION>Alta Bounce</ORGANIZATION>. When not skiing, playing the drums, or listening to <PERSON>Louis Armstrong</PERSON>, he was a passionate and studious golfer at <ORGANIZATION>The Country Club</ORGANIZATION> of <LOCATION>Fairfield</LOCATION>, where he became President as his father had been. Chas also dedicated himself to <ORGANIZATION>Fairfield Country Day School</ORGANIZATION> as a long serving Trustee. Never happier than when out in the garden weeding, clipping, planting or supervising, he cherished his land at Mountain Meadow Farm in <LOCATION>Weston</LOCATION>, <LOCATION>VT</LOCATION>. Starting in <DATE>1964</DATE> with 20 acres and finishing with 192 acres, his careful and exacting stewardship of the trails, meadows, stonewalls, barn, milk house, sugar shack, and house may be his proudest legacy. He is survived by his wife, his sisters, <PERSON>Clare Rimmer</PERSON> of <LOCATION>Kennebunkport</LOCATION>, ME and <LOCATION>Exeter</LOCATION>, <ORGANIZATION>NH</ORGANIZATION>, <PERSON>Mollie Fair</PERSON> of <LOCATION>Charleston</LOCATION>, SC, and sons, <PERSON>John Talbot Curtis II</PERSON> of <LOCATION>London England</LOCATION>, <PERSON>Timothy Whitaker Curtis</PERSON> of <LOCATION>Fairfield</LOCATION>, CT, and <PERSON>Charles Buckley Curtis Jr.</PERSON> of <LOCATION>Waitsfield</LOCATION>, VT, along with seven skiing grandchildren. 1/3
headline: {main:Paid Notice: Deaths  CURTIS, <PERSON>CHARLES BUCKLEY<\/PERSON>}
